abstract.para: This article offers some automation solutions for &sap; administrators. With &salt; formulas, it helps to efficiently configure &ha; and &sap; systems. The solutions that is described here works from &slsreg; 12 SP3 and beyond. All packages are available in the &sles4sapa; module.

note.title: About Official &suse; Support
note.para: The referenced &salt; formulas install and configure &sles4sapreg; including advanced configurations like &hana; System Replication setup and configure the &ha; cluster. The &salt; formulas are part of &sles4sapreg; and fully supported by &suse;. The other parts that belong to the infrastructure (like machines, network, disk formats, mount points) need to be done with &suma;, &ay;, or &terraform;. Keep in mind, our &terraform; project is currently published as-is and supported by the open-source community. For more information, see .

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: Starting from the idea of modernizing and simplifying &hana; and &nw; deployments, &suse; engineering worked on rewriting the deployment wizards in &salt;. &salt; is a configuration management system that is also supported by &susemgr; and &slsreg; for any sort of automation.
The major motivation was to improve and simplify the installation of &hana; on &sls;.

The following sections contain a brief overview of available formulas. Each section contains also a link to the upstream GitHub project. There you can find additional documentation on how to use and apply the formulas.

sect1.title: Terminology
sect1.remark: toms 2020-06-23: add more terms and further explanations?

listitem.para: A scripting language. It interacts with lower-layer utilities such as &crmshell; and several &sap; commands, including &hana; management tools.

A configuration infrastructure management system written in Python. Due to its modular approach, it is often referred as &saltstack;.
&salt; has as a client/server architecture. The server (also called the &saltmaster;) acts as a central control unit for the &salt; clients. The other supported setup option is called masterless.

Static data about &salt; clients. Grains contain information about the operating system that is running, the CPU architecture in use, and much more. Grains can also be set to assign values to &salt; clients.
Formulas are pre-written &salt; States.
For more information about &salt;, refer to the upstream documentation at .

Manages the infrastructure and the &salt; clients within it. It can execute commands remotely on &salt; clients and manage their state. The &saltmaster; captures grains sent from &salt; clients and decide what to do with this information.
A server or machine often controlled by the &saltmaster;. Its main purpose is to execute commands sent from the &saltmaster;, report data back, and send information about itself.
YAML text file to maintain consistency across your environment. &salt; states can be executed.
An infrastructure as code software tool. It deploys the required infrastructure in cloud or virtual environments and &ay; for on-premises deployments.

sect1.title: Using &salt; Formulas
sect1.para: &salt; formulas can be applied in two ways:

formalpara.title: &saltmaster; with &salt; Client
formalpara.para: All steps in must be executed on the &saltmaster; machine.

formalpara.title: &salt; Client only
formalpara.para: All steps in must be executed in all of the &salt; clients where the formulas are going to be executed.

sect1.para: The following procedure is written in a general way to make it fit for all use cases. You need some knowledge about &salt; and how to customize it to your needs.

procedure.title: Applying &salt; Formulas
procedure.para: In this procedure, we show how to create a pillar structure for a system with &hana;, &netweaver;, and with DRBD. All this uses &sles4sap;.

step.para: Install the &salt; formulas with zypper. Get the package name from the upstream GitHub repository.
The pillar files work as configuration files for the &salt; formulas and are intended as user input. To use the files, create a top.sls file which references other files you want to apply.
Create the directory /srv/pillar and its subdirectories hana, netweaver, and drbd:
The directory names match with the names in the top.sls file (see next step).
Create the file /srv/pillar/top.sls with the following content:
step.screen:
base: 'hana01,hana02': - hana.hana - hana.cluster
'netweaver01,netweaver02': - netweaver.netweaver - netweaver.cluster
'drbd01,drbd02': - drbd.drbd - drbd.cluster

step.para: Download the examples from the upstream GitHub repository:
Copy all pillar files to the right directory:
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;cp -vi hana.sls cluster.sls /srv/pillar/hana &prompt.sudo;cp -vi netweaver.sls cluster.sls /srv/pillar/netweaver &prompt.sudo;cp -vi drbd.sls cluster.sls /srv/pillar/drbd

step.para: Modify the content of the pillar files for each &salt; formula, according to the configuration you need.
Notice that, in this example, we have three different cluster.sls files. Each might have different HA cluster requirements.
Create the file /srv/salt/top.sls with the following content:
step.screen:
base: 'hana01,hana02': - hana - cluster
'netweaver01,netweaver02': - netweaver - cluster
'drbd01,drbd02': - drbd - cluster
step.para: In the above example, folder part is removed, as we are pointing to the formulas with their names.

sect1.title: &hana; Automated Deployment
sect1.para: Use the &salt; formula saphanabootstrap-formula for bootstrapping and managing &hana; platform and system replication.
The &salt; formula takes care of the following

listitem.para: Installs &hana;.
Configures system replication.
Preconfigures the &ha; cluster requirements.
Configures the &hana; Prometheus exporter

sect1.para: The &salt; formula can be used in these scenarios:

listitem.para: &hana; single instance automated deployment.
Two &hana; instances on system replication setup.
Two &hana; instances on system replication and cluster scale-up performance-optimized configuration.
Two &hana; instances on system replication setup, cluster scale-up cost-optimized configuration, and extra &hana; installation on a secondary host.
Cloud Service Provides (Azure, AWS, and GCP) automated adjustments for each provider as best-practice.
